conversation.content: [quietly] Te pedí que bajaras porque necesitaba mostrarte estos scans yo misma, no mandarlos por algún portal del hospital o que otro doctor te los explicara.
[wary] No me has llamado en 3 años, y de repente me estás llamando al trabajo diciendo que es urgente por los dolores de cabeza de mamá, so what exactly am I looking at here?
[measured] El contraste muestra un glioblastoma multiforme en el lóbulo temporal izquierdo, aproximadamente 4 centímetros, with significant edema and midline shift already visible.
[stunned pause] Eso es cáncer cerebral. ¿Me estás diciendo que mamá tiene cáncer cerebral y estás usando todos estos términos clínicos como si fuera una de tus estudiantes de medicina?
Es grado 4, which means it's aggressive, y ya infiltró el tejido circundante más allá de lo que podemos ver en las imágenes. [exhales heavily]
¿Cuánto tiempo?
[softly] Con tratamiento, la supervivencia media es típicamente de 14 a 16 meses, pero la posición del tumor de mamá hace que la cirugía sea complicada y ya está mostrando síntomas neurológicos.
Jesús. [shaky exhale]
[struggling] He visto miles de estos scans en mi carrera, le he dado esta noticia a cientos de familias, but seeing Mom's name on the file just completely broke my clinical detachment.
[bitter] Así que ahora necesitas a tu hermanita otra vez, después de todos esos años diciéndome que vendí mi alma a Wall Street, que elegí el dinero sobre la medicina como papá quería.
[defensive] No es por eso que te llamé—mamá nos necesita a las dos ahora, and whatever happened between us doesn't matter when we're talking about her remaining time.
Tienes razón, sé que tienes razón, pero [voice cracking], no puedo procesar esto mientras estás ahí parada con tu bata blanca siendo tan malditamente compuesta sobre nuestra madre muriendo.
No estoy compuesta para nada—vomité dos veces después de revisar sus scans, and I haven't slept in 48 hours trying to find any study or trial that might help.
[firmly] El dinero no es problema para el tratamiento. Whatever experimental therapy exists, dondequiera que estén los mejores especialistas, lo puedo hacer realidad en días.
Hay un ensayo de inmunoterapia en Johns Hopkins para el que podría calificar, pero la tasa de aceptación es menos del 10 por ciento y los resultados todavía son mayormente sin probar.
Conozco al jefe de oncología ahí de una inversión en biotecnología que hicimos juntos—I can have her evaluated by Monday if you think there's even a chance.
[weary] Esto es exactamente lo que le daba miedo, ¿sabes? Que solo volveríamos a unirnos por algo terrible, standing in some sterile room planning her final months.
[raw whisper] ¿Ya sabe? ¿Le has dicho lo que me acabas de decir a mí, o querías que estuviéramos juntas cuando lo escuchara?
Ella sabe que algo está mal por los síntomas, pero no pude explicarle el pronóstico completo hasta que estuvieras aquí. [voice dropping]
[resolved] Entonces vamos a decirle juntas, and we figure out how to make whatever time she has left mean something more than our stupid grudges.

original_conversation.content: [quietly] I asked you to come down because I needed to show you these scans myself, not send them through some hospital portal or have another doctor explain them.
[wary] You haven't called me in three years, and suddenly you're paging me at work saying it's urgent about Mom's headaches, so what exactly am I looking at here?
[measured] The contrast enhancement shows a glioblastoma multiforme in the left temporal lobe, approximately four centimeters, with significant edema and midline shift already visible.
[stunned pause] That's brain cancer. You're telling me Mom has brain cancer and you're using all these clinical terms like I'm one of your medical students?
It's grade four, which means it's aggressive and has already infiltrated surrounding tissue beyond what we can see on the imaging. [exhales heavily]
How long?
[softly] With treatment, median survival is typically fourteen to sixteen months, but Mom's tumor position makes surgery complicated and she's already showing neurological symptoms.
Jesus Christ. [shaky exhale]
[struggling] I've looked at thousands of these scans over my career, told hundreds of families this news, but seeing Mom's name on the file just completely broke my clinical detachment.
[bitter] So now you need your little brother again, after all those years of telling me I sold my soul to Wall Street, that I chose money over medicine like Dad wanted.
[defensive] That's not why I called you here—Mom needs both of us now, and whatever happened between us doesn't matter when we're talking about her remaining time.
You're right, I know you're right, but [voice cracking], I can't process this while you're standing there in your white coat being so goddamn composed about our mother dying.
I'm not composed at all—I threw up twice after reviewing her scans and haven't slept in forty-eight hours trying to find any study or trial that might help.
[firmly] Money isn't an issue for treatment. Whatever experimental therapy exists, wherever the best specialists are, I can make it happen within days.
There's an immunotherapy trial at Johns Hopkins that she might qualify for, but the acceptance rate is less than ten percent and the results are still largely unproven.
I know the chief of oncology there from a biotech investment we did together—I can have her evaluated by Monday if you think there's even a chance.
[weary] This is exactly what she was afraid of, you know—that we'd only come together again over something terrible, standing in some sterile room planning her final months.
[raw whisper] Does she know yet? Have you told her what you just told me, or did you want us to be there together when she hears it?
She knows something's wrong from the symptoms, but I couldn't bring myself to explain the full prognosis until you were here. [voice dropping]
[resolved] Then we go tell her together, and we figure out how to make whatever time she has left mean something more than our stupid grudges.

scenario: A radiologist must inform their estranged sibling, now a successful hedge fund manager, that the scans they've just reviewed show their mother has an aggressive brain tumor.
